displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: I see. Doctor: So but it can never be like you get the pill and you get the placebo Pill that can't ever happen. That's just not ethical. And the IRB and all of our regulatory people would literally have spazz attack and we would never do that. Patient: Okay. Family Member 3: Okay. Doctor: So just to put that at ease. You know, it's- there's a lot of myths going around. And some of it is founded in just the confusion, you know, like, we’ve gotten so complicated on how we do things now. And sometimes the description of that explanation isn't as maybe as thorough or you just, you know, I may say it, but you didn't really receive it. So there's a lot of that and the more complicated we get with our treatments, the worse that occurs. And to tell you the truth, part of the things that we always try to study and why you guys are graciously signed up is, you know, I may say something go, “No, no, no, I reviewed that with them.” And you guys are like, “Oh, honey, I've never heard it.” So we want to make sure whatever we're doing actually could be optimized, because it is complicated. Family Member 1: So you are going to put him on the docetaxel pill? Doctor: Right or you might get on just the regular IV. So the trial is not that you get both, but you're one or the other. Family Member 1: When will you know that? Doctor: Yeah, so this is where it gets complicated. I'm gonna have my research nurse M_____ come in, it's always the devils in the details. Family Member 1: Okay. Doctor: What's tight about this and what's goofy about it and we've already shared this with a company is that they almost want to be like, okay, we know everything about you. And then two weeks later, you have to start. So there's a time thing that's so compressed, that I even fear that you might even, you know, need another CAT scan, because they only want everything done in a two week window. So if that's the case, obviously, she'll time it out. But I defer to the research team to make sure that that's done correctly. And I've learned over the years to basically zip it because I say something they're like, “Yeah, no, you just botched up that schedule.” So I just stay out of it and let Melanie take over. Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s what I’m sayin’. So, Doctor: Yes. So, maybe it’s something Patient: That’s all, so what it does, is that a fact, can it happen like that? Can they do that? Like, is it, like I had diarrhea before, Doctor: Yeah. Are you taking any laxative or a stool softener or anything? Patient: Yeah. That’s what I’m sayin’ to you that stool softener don’t Doctor: Stop that then, because that’s, uh, worsening your diarrhea. Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast.

Patient: March first I start Medicare plus a supplement. Doctor: Yeah. Maybe with part D? Family Member: Yes. Patient: D and F, I think. Doctor: That would be great. So again, we may want to ask our pharmacy to look at the medicine next week once you’re on Medicare. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, because again, they will pay eighty percent. Patient: Right. Doctor: Then the other twenty percent depending on sort of other plans you might have, you’ll probably end up spending about five thousand dollars. Huh, then you’ll go into the donut and then you don’t have to pay the rest of that. Patient: Well, they said the, huh, supplement plan that I’ve got now, I shouldn’t have to pay nothing out of pocket. Family Member: For normal trials. Patient: For normal things. Family Member: Right.

Patient: Hum. Doctor: That wasn’t big before, what we’ve got there. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: So we’re going to meet again after so we all describe the tests together so that you know what it is like. Family Member: Oh, okay. Patient: Essentially again with the shot and stuff, it didn’t change. Doctor: Exactly. No. You’re great. You had the last shot June sixth. You’re fine with that. So we’re going to extend it a week or two. Patient: Going to the bathroom. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. You’re eating fine. Patient: I’m eating fine. I’m eating good. Patient: I’m going to eat right now. Doctor: Oh. You’re taking her to lunch?

Patient: I feel great. Doctor: I was going to say, you look great. I know this is you know waah why can’t we just get this done. But I don’t want to miss anything for you. Patient: Ahhh no I feel great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I have no problems… Doctor: That’s awesome. Patient: …not that I know of. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And then that’s the lung doctor to look up these nodules in your lungs and that’s Dr. S___. And then when you come back it will be March eighth which is time for you next Lupron shot. And we’ll get bloodwork then too to make sure that you’re not rising on that number. Patient: Okay so now I just got to get an appointment today for these? Doctor: Yep when you walk out to where you checked in. Patient: Um hmmm.

Family Member: You can handle that. Doctor: Yeah, there is like a you know, plus minus, so if it’s like a special thing you know, might be five or six weeks so we can work with you guys. Because people have lives and they take vacation, they have other things they gotta do. Family Member: Right Doctor: That isn’t just cancer. Family Member: Actually I thought it was going to be worse, but you’re saying it’s every three weeks or so. I’m pretty surprised. I’m surprised. Doctor: Yeah, for standard dosing, just no trial, just once for an hour every three weeks is the infusion. Of course you know, I K_____ world that's a half a day, but still, it's not you know, every day you have to be here or anything like that. Family Member: He can’t get it at K_____ C____? Doctor: Not if it’s a trial. If it’s a trial. Family Member: If it’s not a trial he could get it at K____ C_____? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, well you'd have to get the doctor up there to give it like I can't prescribe it and you do it there. But we can have you go see. Family Member: Are you sure? Patient: Dr. F_____.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You got that. Patient: Okay, right, right. Now let me ask you this, I got about four left. Doctor: Of what? Patient: Uh Norco. Do you want me to dispose of them too? Doctor: No you can use them. Patient: I’m not…
DOC That you can use , that I’m not too worried about. I’m not going until… Doctor: If you only have four left I’m not too worried about that. Patient: Okay I ain’t going down to the prescription place until Wednesday. Doctor: Okay. That’s fine. Then use them until then. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Yeah you’ll need them. Patient: Okay. I got…

Family Member: Yes, yes. And your knowledge you know. You have so much knowledge, you know, different trials and medicines Doctor: You'll help me, you know my family is not in medicine. Family Member: Oh really? Doctor: But sometimes I get accused of speaking in too much medical lingo. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So if you don't, because a lot of my friends are doctors obviously. Family Member: Right right. Doctor: But so if what I'm saying doesn't make sense or if I'm using terms that are not familiar to you, please just stop me and and just say what do you mean by that? Or that we haven't heard that before. Family Member: You’re very thorough. You can tell you’re a teacher. Doctor: Both of my parents are teachers. So they’ll be happy to hear that. Doctor: All right, okay, those that's your classwork from this session today, okay? All right. So let me go make a copy of this so that you have this for your records in the answers and get that blood drawn. And then I'll contact the research nurses and let them know that. Okay, all right. I'll be right back.

Patient: I want the best of what the best is for. Doctor: Yeah, No, I know. Patient: you know. Doctor: Well, but you’re a guy that doesn’t you know sit around. I mean part of the thing that we wanted to do earlier this year was just like knock out what you can knock out which you did. So, I’m sorry that we’re at this point but let’s not be sorry, let’s just do something about it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, are you due for a shot today? Patient: I don’t know. The last one I had was in June. Doctor: Okay, I think you are so I’m gonna give this to J____ so we can just get everything on one paper because I don’t want to lose track of your next injection either. So, your Lupron stays in the background, we fart around with all this. Patient: Well, I took that in, Lupron and then all this. Doctor: In June or August? Oh, do I give you the Lupron? Oh, I don’t, Patient: No, Dr___ I had went to him in August. Doctor: okay. That’s why I don’t know, got it, yep. Patient: And I go back I think it’s in March. He gave me a six month shot this time.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: That might take a minute. Patient: Okay. Family Member: In addition to the radium or that? Doctor: No, that is the radium. Patient: Oh, that is the radium. Doctor: Yeah. So, there’s different names. Family Member: Oh, I got you. Doctor: Radium, there’s liquid radiation, there’s Xofigo, which is the trade name, and, you know, we don’t give it but the radiation oncology doctors give it because it is a form of radiation. So, they’ll go over everything but what I would do is we would start the prior authorization process with our insurance but you then would talk to the radiation oncology doctor for a formal consultation and then they go over the pros and cons of what’s gonna happen and so on and so on. Patient: You know about it I’m sure about this. You know about the radiation that I had Doctor: Uh huh. Yep Patient: and is it similar to that or is the… Doctor: Different.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: You’ll stop your abiraterone. Stay on the prednisone. I’ll check insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, I’ll bring you back in a month no matter what. Huh, if you’re interested and you have insurance clearance, I may ask the nurse just to give you a call at home. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And say, hey, uh, it seems good. If you’re interested, you can come in this week and then we can get things started. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So the visit with me is just a placeholder so you don’t fall through the cracks. Patient: Okay. Right. Doctor: Okay? So I do that with everyone. I just want to make sure that, huh, some of this back and forth stuff, you know, that if you haven’t heard anything, you know you’re going to still see me, huh, but if you heard something before then we’ll just move forward. Patient: Okay. Doctor: What question does that bring up for you? Patient: I think, I think you answered all my questions pretty good. Huh, the only thing, the chemo.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: And things like that where it looks good in the bottle but there’s no regulation on what’s inside. Remember we talked about how difficult that can be sometimes? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And then I don’t know what’s going to happen if your liver poops out on me then we’re in trouble. Family Member: Right. Because it can affect his liver. Patient: Okay. And that was the same thing with the magnesium. Right? Doctor: Correct Patient: Because you advised no magnesium? Doctor: Well, no. A normal level of magnesium is good. Patient: A normal level Family Member: Like in a multivitamin magnesium? Doctor: Correct. Yes.

Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Hopefully, it hasn’t changed in two weeks. Doctor: Your sugars are high, though. Are you on – remind me, Are you diabetic? I can’t remember. Patient: Yeah. I have type two diabetes. Doctor: So, your sugar was high today. Three hundred. You probably didn’t fast. Family Member: No, he didn’t fast. Patient: No, I didn’t. Family Member: He had a donut. Doctor: Yeah, there you go. Patient: It was really good. Doctor: Good.

Family Member: They say it’s the large- it’s about the size of Connecticut. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: So, actually, we was there most of the day. We was like falling asleep on the safari because you’ve got a, they gotta run and catch the animals. Patient: Oh. No. We went to lunch. We went to lunch. (& FAM talking the same time) Doctor: So you’re just kind of driving around, and they’re like, hey, there’s a, there’s a giraffe or something? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. (Laughter) Family Member: Everybody’s like taking pictures. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. She took some good pictures with our camera. I ain’t lying. She took some good pictures. Doctor: And so do you have to drive like far from where you’re staying to get to the park? Is that why you have to get up so early? Family Member: Well they, because the animals is up early. Patient: No. Doctor: No. But I mean you’re not like driving three hours to get there?

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: so I want to share it with you guys. Other than that, this is not like chemo. This is not like anything else. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: So the tiredness is the top three that really will be wiping you out. Sometimes it makes you feel so wiped out… Patient: Wait a minute, W__ I got a compliment for you Healthcare Professional: Uh, huh? Patient: Doctor- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -hold on for one second. Doctor: Oh, okay. Healthcare Professional: Uh,huh. Patient: So you said, you said well I know you got the six hundred Motrin, you got eight hundred Motrin, but then we had the morphine and all that other stuff.
